claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 106:
(1) A subagent represents the principal with respect to acts within the scope of the authority thereof.
(2) A subagent has the same rights and obligations as an agent in relation to the principal and third parties within the scope of that subagent's authority.
(Abuse of Authority to Represent)



        Conclusion:
        A guardian of adult may not appoint its sub-agent unless there is an unavoidable reason to do so..'''
supporting_argument: If a guardian of an adult appoints a sub-agent, they must ensure that it aligns with Article 106 which states that a subagent must act within the scope of their authority and have the same rights and obligations as an agent. This implies that the appointment of a sub-agent by a guardian should only occur under specific, unavoidable circumstances to maintain the integrity and legal obligations stipulated by the statute.
attacking_argument: The given argument does not logically entail the conclusion because Article 106 does not specify any restrictions on subagents appointed by guardians of adults, nor does it mention the necessity of an 'unavoidable reason' for appointing a sub-agent. The conclusion introduces a new condition ('unavoidable reason') not supported by the premises.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 353:
A pledgee of movables may, if the pledged thing is usurped, recover the same solely by filing an action for recovery of possession.
(Enforcement of Pledges on Movables)



        Conclusion:
        If the possession of the pledgee of a pledge on movable property is stolen by a third party, the pledgee can demand the return based on the pledge..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 353, if the pledged movable property is usurped, the pledgee has the legal right to recover the property by filing an action for recovery of possession. This implies that in the scenario where the possession of the pledgee's movable property is stolen by a third party, the pledgee can indeed demand the return of the property based on the pledge, as the stolen possession falls under the category of 'usurped' as per the statute.
attacking_argument: The conclusion does not logically follow from the premise because Article 353 specifically states that the pledgee can recover possession by filing an action for recovery of possession if the pledged thing is usurped, not that they can demand return based on the pledge itself. The premise does not mention the right to demand return based on the pledge, only the recovery of possession of the pledged item if it is usurped.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 139:
When a period is provided for in hours, the period commences immediately at the specified time.



        Conclusion:
        If an agreement is made at 10:00 a.m. on June 3 of a given year that the obligation will be fulfilled within five hours,the period commences at 10:00 a.m. of the same day, which does not fall on Sunday, holiday as provided in the Act on National Holidays, or any other holiday..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 139, when a period is provided in hours, it commences immediately at the specified time. Therefore, if an agreement is made at 10:00 a.m. on June 3 of a given year to fulfill an obligation within five hours, the period starts immediately at 10:00 a.m. of the same day, assuming the day does not fall on a Sunday, national holiday, or any other holiday as defined by the Act on National Holidays.
attacking_argument: The conclusion may not logically follow from the premise if the specified time falls on a Sunday or a national holiday, as Article 139 does not explicitly state that such periods commence on holidays or Sundays regardless of their status. Therefore, if June 3 were a Sunday or a holiday, the period would not commence at 10:00 a.m. on that day, which contradicts the conclusion.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 102:
An act that a person with qualified legal capacity performs as an agent of another person may not be rescinded on the grounds of qualified legal capacity; provided, however, that this does not apply to an act performed by a person with qualified legal capacity as a legal representative of another person with qualified legal capacity.
(Authority of an Agent with No Specifically Defined Authority)



        Conclusion:
        A contract may not be rescinded by the principal after it is performed by an agent with a counterparty even if it turns out that the agent was a person with limited capacity..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 102, an act performed by an agent on behalf of another person cannot be rescinded solely on the grounds of the agent's qualified legal capacity, unless the agent was also a legal representative of another person with qualified legal capacity. Therefore, if an agent with limited capacity enters into a contract on behalf of a principal, the principal cannot rescind the contract after it has been performed by the agent, as long as the agent was not also a legal representative of another person with qualified legal capacity.
attacking_argument: The conclusion may not logically follow from the premises because Article 102 specifically excludes acts performed by a person with qualified legal capacity as a legal representative of another person with qualified legal capacity from being non-rescindable. It does not explicitly cover or rule out the case of an agent who is a person with limited capacity. Therefore, it cannot be concluded that a contract performed by an agent with limited capacity cannot be rescinded by the principal, as the statute does not address this specific scenario.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 103:
An agent who has no specifically defined authority has the authority to perform the following acts only:
(i) acts of preservation; and
(ii) acts with the purpose of using or improving a thing or right that is the subject matter of the agency, to the extent that this does not change the nature of that thing or right.
(Appointment of Subagents by Agents)



        Conclusion:
        An agent who has no specified authority shall have the authority only to do the acts of preservation..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 103, an agent without specifically defined authority is permitted to perform acts of preservation. This directly supports the conclusion that an agent who has no specified authority shall have the authority only to do the acts of preservation, as it is explicitly stated in the statute that such an agent's authority includes acts of preservation.
attacking_argument: The conclusion does not fully reflect the scope of authority as described in Article 103, as it omits the agent's authority to perform acts with the purpose of using or improving the subject matter of the agency, which was included in the original article.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 9:
A juridical act performed by an adult ward is voidable; provided, however, that this does not apply to the purchase of daily necessities or to any other act involved in day-to-day life.
(Rescission of Decisions for Commencement of Guardianship)



        Conclusion:
        The purchase of daily household items may not be rescinded, even if an adult ward performed the act..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 9, any juridical act performed by an adult ward is generally voidable, except for the purchase of daily necessities or acts involved in day-to-day life. Therefore, if an adult ward purchases daily household items, this specific act falls under the exception and cannot be rescinded, making the conclusion valid.
attacking_argument: The conclusion that the purchase of daily household items may not be rescinded, even if an adult ward performed the act, does not logically follow from the given premise. Article 9 only states that such purchases are exempt from being voidable, but it does not explicitly state that these purchases cannot be rescinded under any circumstances. There might be other legal provisions or circumstances not mentioned in Article 9 that could allow for the rescission of such purchases.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 646:
(1) A mandatary must deliver to the mandator monies and other things received during the course of administering the mandated business. The same applies to fruits the mandatary has reaped.
(2) A mandatary must transfer to the mandator rights that the mandatary has acquired in the mandatary's own name on behalf of the mandator.
(Mandatary's Responsibility for Consumption of Monies)



        Conclusion:
        The mandatary is not obligated to deliver to the mandator civil fruits reaped during the course of administering the mandated business..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 646(1), a mandatary is required to deliver to the mandator all monies and other things received during the course of administering the mandated business, as well as fruits reaped. However, the conclusion specifically states that the mandatary is not obligated to deliver civil fruits, which implies that civil fruits are excluded from the scope of 'fruits' mentioned in Article 646(1), suggesting a possible exception or interpretation that civil fruits are not covered by the statute.
attacking_argument: The conclusion contradicts Article 646(1) which states that the mandatary must deliver to the mandator not only monies and other things received but also fruits reaped. Since civil fruits are a form of fruits reaped, the conclusion that the mandatary is not obligated to deliver civil fruits is invalid.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 140:
When a period is provided for in days, weeks, months, or years, the first day of the period is not included in the computation; provided, however, that this does not apply when the period commences at twelve midnight.
(Expiration of Period)



        Conclusion:
        If an agreement is made at 3:00 p.m. on May 16 of a given year that the obligation will be fulfilled within one week, the period commences at twelve midnight of the same day, which does not fall on Sunday, holiday as provided in the Act on National Holidays, or any other holiday..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 140, if the agreement is made at 3:00 p.m. on May 16 and the period commences at twelve midnight of the same day, it falls outside the conditions where the first day of the period is not included in the computation, thus the obligation will be fulfilled within one week starting from midnight on May 16, which is in line with the conclusion.
attacking_argument: The conclusion contradicts Article 140, which states that the first day of the period is not included in the computation unless the period commences at twelve midnight. The conclusion assumes that the period commences at twelve midnight of the same day without explicitly stating that the agreement was made at twelve midnight, thus it is not necessarily true that the period starts at midnight based solely on the given premises.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 487:
If there is an instrument evidencing a claim and the person making the performance has made full performance, that person may demand the return of the instrument.
(Appropriation of One Payment or Delivery among Two or More Obligations Requiring the Same Kind of Payment or Delivery)



        Conclusion:
        In cases where there is any instrument which evidences the claim for wages, the borrower may assert the fact that he/she will make a payment by returning and exchanging the instrument when attempting to make the performance has completed his/her entire performance..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 487, if an individual has made full performance as required by their obligations, they are entitled to demand the return of the instrument that evidences their claim. In the context of wages, if a borrower has fulfilled their obligations in full, they can rightfully assert the return and exchange of the instrument as a means of payment, thus supporting the conclusion that they may make such a demand upon completion of their performance.
attacking_argument: The conclusion does not logically follow from the premise because Article 487 specifically refers to an instrument evidencing a claim and the appropriation of one payment or delivery among two or more obligations requiring the same kind of payment or delivery. It does not explicitly state or imply that this applies to the specific case of wages or the borrower's right to exchange the instrument when attempting to fulfill a performance obligation. The premise does not provide enough context or specificity to support the conclusion that the borrower may assert the fact of returning and exchanging the instrument specifically for wages.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 243:
If two or more movable properties with different owners can no longer be separated without damage due to accession, the ownership of the composite thing belongs to the owner of the principal movable property. The same applies if excessive expense is required to separate the movables.



        Conclusion:
        If two or more movables with different owners are so joined to each other that they can no longer be separated without damaging the same, ownership of the composite Thing shall vest in the owner of the principal movables..'''
supporting_argument: Article 243 explicitly states that if movable properties with different owners are joined in such a way that they cannot be separated without damage, the ownership of the composite thing belongs to the owner of the principal movable property. This directly supports the conclusion that in cases where movables are joined and cannot be separated without damaging them, ownership of the composite thing should vest in the owner of the principal movables.
attacking_argument: The conclusion does not necessarily follow from the premise as Article 243 specifies conditions under which ownership is determined only when 'excessive expense' or 'damage' is involved in separating the movables. The conclusion, however, does not include the condition of 'excessive expense' as a requirement for determining ownership, which makes it broader than the premise and not strictly entailed by it.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 300:
The exercise of a right of retention does not preclude the running of extinctive prescription of claims.
(Extinction of Rights of Retention by Provision of Security)



        Conclusion:
        The extinctive prescription of the claim secured by the right of retention does not run while the holder of the right of retention exercises the right of retention and retains the subject matter..'''
supporting_argument: The exercise of a right of retention, as stated in Article 300, does not interfere with the running of extinctive prescription of claims. Therefore, the claim secured by the right of retention continues to be subject to extinctive prescription only until the right of retention is exercised. Once the right of retention is exercised, the prescription does not run, supporting the conclusion that the claim secured by the right of retention remains unaffected by the prescription while the right is being exercised.
attacking_argument: The conclusion contradicts Article 300, which states that the exercise of a right of retention does not affect the running of extinctive prescription for claims. Therefore, the prescription period should continue to run even if the right of retention is exercised.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 192:
A person that commences the possession of movables peacefully and openly by a transactional act acquires the rights that are exercised with respect to the movables immediately if the person possesses it in good faith and without negligence.
(Recovery of Stolen or Lost Property)



        Conclusion:
        A took the jewelry that B had forgotten, believing without negligence that it belonged to A. In this case, A may not obtain the ownership of the jewelry by good faith acquisition..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 192, good faith and the absence of negligence are necessary conditions for acquiring ownership through possession. In the case described, although A possesses the jewelry in good faith and without negligence, the jewelry originally belongs to B, who merely forgot it. Since B did not voluntarily transfer possession to A, the conditions for good faith acquisition as per Article 192 are not met, thus A cannot obtain ownership of the jewelry.
attacking_argument: The conclusion contradicts Article 192, which states that a person who acquires movables in good faith and without negligence, through a peaceful and open transactional act, immediately acquires the rights with respect to those movables. If A believed in good faith and without negligence that the jewelry belonged to them, Article 192 would support A's acquisition of ownership, contrary to the conclusion provided.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 356:
The pledgee of immovables may use and profit from the immovables that are the subject matter of a pledge in line with the way the relevant immovables are used.
(Management Expenses Borne by Pledgees of Immovables)



        Conclusion:
        In pledges of immovables, pledgees and a pledgors may conclude a special provision that the pledgees may not use and receive the profits from the immovable property that is the subject matter of the pledge..'''
supporting_argument: Article 356 establishes a general rule that pledgees of immovables can use and profit from the immovables they pledge, but the conclusion states that a special provision can be made where pledgees do not use or profit from the pledged immovables, which does not contradict Article 356 as it allows for exceptions or special agreements between the pledgee and pledgor.
attacking_argument: The conclusion contradicts Article 356, which states that pledgees of immovables may use and profit from the immovables. If Article 356 is assumed to be true, then it logically follows that pledgees have the right to use and profit from the pledged immovables, which is incompatible with a special provision that prohibits pledgees from using and profiting from the pledged immovables.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 655:
The grounds of termination of mandate may not be asserted against the other party unless the other party was notified of or knew of the same.
(Quasi-Mandate)



        Conclusion:
        Regardless of the other party's knowledge, the grounds of termination of mandate may not be asserted against the other party unless the other party was notified of the same..'''
supporting_argument: Article 655 explicitly states that the grounds for terminating a mandate cannot be enforced unless the other party has been notified or is aware of these grounds. Therefore, the conclusion directly follows from the premise, maintaining that notification is a necessary condition for the assertion of termination grounds, regardless of the other party's knowledge.
attacking_argument: The conclusion does not fully capture the intent of Article 655, as it omits the condition that the grounds of termination may not be asserted if the other party 'knew of the same' without needing notification. This implies that there are two conditions for not being able to assert the grounds of termination: either the other party was not notified, or they did not know about it, which the conclusion simplifies to only the notification condition.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 371:
If there is a default with respect to a claim secured by a mortgage, the mortgage extends to the fruits of the mortgaged immovables derived after the default.
(Mutatis Mutandis Application of Provisions on Right of Retention)



        Conclusion:
        In cases where a mortgagor lease land which is a subject matter of the mortgage to a person, the mortgage shall extend to the rent without a default with respect to a claim secured by the mortgage..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 371, if there is a default with respect to a claim secured by a mortgage, the mortgage extends to the fruits of the mortgaged immovables derived after the default. This indicates that the mortgage can cover not only the mortgaged property but also any benefits or income generated from it. In the context of leasing land subject to a mortgage, rent can be considered as a form of fruit or income derived from the mortgaged immovable. Therefore, the conclusion logically follows that the mortgage extends to the rent, provided that a default has occurred, aligning with the mutatis mutandis application of the provisions on the right of retention.
attacking_argument: The conclusion does not logically follow from the premise because Article 371 specifically states that the mortgage extends to the fruits of the mortgaged immovables only after a default with respect to a claim secured by the mortgage. The conclusion, however, claims that the mortgage extends to the rent without any default having occurred.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 244:
If the distinction of principal and accessory cannot be made between the movables united by accession, the owner of each movable property co-owns the composite thing in proportion to the respective price current at the time of the accession.
(Mixture)



        Conclusion:
        If the distinction of principal and accessory cannot be made between the joined movables, based on a demand by one or several owners of each of the movables, the owners shall be determined by court..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 244, when it is impossible to distinguish between the principal and accessory in a mixture of movables, the ownership is divided among the owners of the original movables in proportion to their value at the time of the accession. This article provides a legal framework for determining ownership in such cases, thereby supporting the conclusion that in situations where the distinction cannot be made, the court should determine the owners based on the legal principles outlined in Article 244.
attacking_argument: The conclusion does not logically follow from the premise as Article 244 does not mention any role for a court in determining ownership when the distinction between principal and accessory cannot be made. The article only specifies how ownership is shared when the movables are mixed, without indicating a need for judicial intervention to determine ownership.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 406:
If the subject matter of the claim is to be determined by a choice being made from among more than one performance, the right to choose belongs to the obligor.
(Exercise of Right to Choose)



        Conclusion:
        If the subject of the claim is to be identified by way of choice among more than one performance, the right to make the choice shall vest in the obligor as long as there is no special provision..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 406, if the subject matter of the claim requires a choice among multiple performances, the right to choose is explicitly stated to belong to the obligor. Therefore, in the absence of any special provisions that might alter this rule, the conclusion that the right to choose vests in the obligor is directly supported by the premise.
attacking_argument: The conclusion does not logically follow from the premise because Article 406 specifies that the right to choose belongs to the obligor only if the subject matter of the claim is determined by a choice among more than one performance, but it does not explicitly state that this right persists in the absence of a special provision. The premise does not cover all scenarios, particularly those where special provisions might alter or negate the obligor's right to choose.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 423-6:
If the obligee files an action concerning the exercise of the subrogor's right, the obligee must give a notice of suit to the obligor without delay.
(Obligee's Right of Subrogation to Preserve the Right to Request Registration)



        Conclusion:
        If the obligee files an action concerning the exercise of the subrogor's right, the obligee must give a notice of suit to the obligor without delay..'''
supporting_argument: Article 423-6 directly states that if the obligee files an action concerning the exercise of the subrogor's right, they must give a notice of suit to the obligor without delay, which logically entails the conclusion.
attacking_argument: The conclusion restates the premise without adding any new logical reasoning or condition that wasn't already present in the premise. Therefore, while the conclusion is logically entailed by the premise, the argument does not demonstrate any additional logical reasoning or analysis beyond mere repetition, which questions the validity of the argument's structure or complexity as a demonstration of logical reasoning skills.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 3-2:
If the person making a juridical act did not have mental capacity when manifesting the relevant intention, the juridical act is void.
Section 3 Capacity to Act
(Age of Majority)



        Conclusion:
        If a party to a contract did not have mental capacity when manifesting the relevant intention, the nullity of the contract may be asserted even against a third party in good faith and acting without negligence..'''
supporting_argument: If a party to a contract lacks mental capacity when manifesting their intention, according to Article 3-2, the juridical act is void. Therefore, the contract is null and void due to the absence of mental capacity, which means that the nullity of the contract can be asserted even against a third party in good faith and acting without negligence.
attacking_argument: The given claim asserts that the conclusion logically follows from the premises, but Article 3-2 only specifies that a juridical act is void if the person lacked mental capacity when manifesting their intention. It does not extend to nullifying contracts against third parties in good faith and acting without negligence. The conclusion overreaches the scope of Article 3-2, which does not address the validity of contract nullification in relation to third parties.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 632:
A contract for work become effective when one of the parties promises to complete work and the other party promises to pay remuneration for the outcome of the work.
(Timing of Payment of Remuneration)



        Conclusion:
        The contractor may not claim his/her remuneration without the specified consent of remuneration amount..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 632, a contract for work becomes effective when one party promises to complete work and the other promises to pay remuneration. This implies that the payment of remuneration is contingent upon the completion of the work and the specified terms agreed upon by both parties. Therefore, the contractor cannot claim remuneration unless it aligns with the consented amount previously agreed upon in the contract.
attacking_argument: The conclusion does not logically follow from the premise provided. Article 632 states the conditions under which a contract for work becomes effective, but it does not specify that the contractor may not claim remuneration without the specified consent of remuneration amount. The premise only mentions the promises made by the parties regarding the completion of work and payment of remuneration, but does not address the conditions under which the contractor can claim the remuneration.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 378:
If a third party that purchases the ownership or superficies of a mortgaged immovables pays the price of the same to a mortgagee at the request of the same mortgagee, that mortgage is terminated for the benefit of that third party.
(Claims for Extinguishment of Mortgages)



        Conclusion:
        A created a mortgage on Land X, owned by A, for the benefit of B and thereafter sold Land X to C. In this case, if C pays the price of the same to B at the request of B, the mortgage shall be terminated..'''
supporting_argument: According to Article 378, if a third party (in this case, C) purchases the ownership of a mortgaged immovable (Land X) and pays the price to the mortgagee (B) at the mortgagee's request, the mortgage is terminated for the benefit of that third party (C). Therefore, since C purchased Land X and paid the price to B at B's request, the mortgage originally created by A for B's benefit is terminated.
attacking_argument: The argument assumes that Article 378 directly applies to the scenario where the seller of the mortgaged property (A) also owns it initially, which might not be explicitly covered by the statute. The statute focuses on a third party paying the mortgagee, but does not specify the seller's role when they are also the owner of the mortgaged property.

claim:
The claim is that the following argument is valid,
        i.e. the premises logically entail the conclusion.

        The following argument consists of several premises in the form of
        statute articles along with a conclusion. The premises can be assumed
        to be true.

        Argument:
        '''Premises in form of statute articles:
        Article 134:
A juridical act subject to a condition precedent is void if the condition is dependent only upon the intention of the obligor.
(Effect of Arrival of Assigned Time)



        Conclusion:
        A juristic act which is subject to a condition precedent shall be void if the condition is dependent upon the will of the obligor..'''
supporting_argument: Article 134 explicitly states that a juridical act subject to a condition precedent is void if the condition is dependent only upon the intention of the obligor. The conclusion directly aligns with this premise, as it asserts that a juristic act subject to a condition precedent shall be void if the condition is dependent upon the will of the obligor, which is synonymous with the intention of the obligor as mentioned in Article 134.
attacking_argument: The conclusion uses the term 'will of the obligor' which is not explicitly stated in Article 134. Article 134 specifies that the condition is void if it is dependent 'only upon the intention of the obligor', which is slightly different from 'dependent upon the will of the obligor'. The term 'will' could imply a broader range of conditions beyond just 'intention', thus the conclusion may not be logically entailed by the given premise.
